comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Clonsilla signal box During the period from 1922 when Ireland was granted 'home rule' by England, a group of' 'Irregulars' were doing their utmost to bring down the government of Eamon DeValera. As part of their campaign they decided that if they destroyed the country's communication system, the government would fall. This beautiful signal box was one of several that were burned down in 1938. It was later rebuilt. www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/history-heritage/arch... Is this before or after the burning and rebuilding?

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: The station opened on 1 September 1848 as a stop on the Dublin-Sligo line, and closed in 1947. As with Drumcondra station, it was reopened in 1981 for commuter services to Dublin city and upgraded in 2000, which involved the building of a new station building. The main line running through the station now is Dublin-Maynooth, with some services running as far west as Longford. The signal box is similar to, but less ornate than the similar boxes to be seen in north county Dublin on the Dublin-Belfast railway line station such as Balbriggan. It was burned down in 1938 by a group of Irregulars intent on bringing down Eamon de Valera's goverment by destroying the country's communications. However the box was rebuilt and to this day the level crossing gates are still manually controlled by wheel, a rarity in today's railway system. www.streetsbroadandnarrow.com/2011/07/clonsilla-railway-s...

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] This was taken, so far as we know, in October 1938. Has to have been before the fire, by the look of the seasoned wood panels behind the instruments, etc.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: 26th June 1996: 71. Mr. Lawlor asked the Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht Michael D. Higgins the plans, if any, he has to address the concerns of residents in the Clonsilla area of Dublin 15 regarding the preservation of the old signal box at Clonsilla Station as part of our transport heritage; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that this signal box may be the last of its kind in the Dublin area and that there is concern that it may be demolished as the line becomes automated; and if he will discuss the heritage aspects of this matter with the relevant bodies to ensure the preservation of the old signal box at Clonsilla, either in situ, or at an adjacent site. [13748/96] Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht (Mr. M. Higgins): This matter has not previously been brought to my attention. However, as the signal box is the property of a public authority, I will request the advice of the Heritage Council as to whether it should be designated as a heritage building under section 10 of the Heritage Act, 1995.

I was looking at this early bridge at Athenry the other day ( Chetham collection ) and comparing it to the present one. I suspect these bridges were changed --and date sometime after 1870-- to allow for greater clearance--as bigger engines, taller flues? --. Or else to make the climb easier on passengers? Athenry was also MGWR and on same line as above.

comment.author: 51964676@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/rossendalewadey] Yes, that's the purpose of the electric train staff instruments. A train cannot enter the single line section unless the driver is in posession of an appropriate staff ( also called a token in some systems). Said staffs are dispensed from the instruments, which requires the signalmen at each end of the section to press buttons at the same time, and placed in those loop holders for easier transfer to the train crew. Another staff for the same section cannot be issued until the first staff has been replaced in the staff instrument at the other end of the section. Therefore, if everyone's done their job properly, only one train can be in the section at a time. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Token_(railway_signalling)
